Title:
New species of Tomentella (Thelephorales, Basidiomycota) from
Xinjiang and a key to species of China
Keywords:
ectomycorrhizal fungi; phylogeny; resupinate thelephoroid
fungi; taxonomy; temperate mixed forest
Abstract:
Species in the genus Tomentella are distributed throughout
the temperate and tropical regions worldwide, but few studies associated
with taxonomy and phylogeny of this genus had been reported from
Northwest China. In this paper, the molecular phylogenetic analyses of
the nuclear ribosomal ITS (internal transcribed spacer: ITS1-5.8S-ITS2)
and LSU (large sub-unit: 28S) sequences combining with morphological
characteristics identified three new species from Xinjiang Autonomous
Region in Northwest China, which were named T. aurantispora, T.
kanasensis and T. schrenkiana. Some similar macromorphological and
anatomical characteristics can be shared for these new species,
including arachnoid basidiocarps, byssoid sterile margins, utriform
basidia with a clamp connection at base, the absence of rhizomorphs and
cystidia, and slightly thick-walled, subglobose to globose
basidiospores. Among these new species, color of the hymenophoral
surface, the size of the basidiospores and some other features can be
spread apart from each other. The new species and closely related
species in the phylogenetic tree were discussed, and a key to the
identified species of Tomentella from China was provided.
